/ConfigRisk/WeakPassword.description: Audit successful login events with weak passwords; passwords that are easily guessed by attackers or cracked by brute-force tools are considered weak, such as '123', 'abc', etc. This account/system is at risk of weak password vulnerabilities. The affected asset is within the internal network (destination address).

/ConfigRisk/Service.label: Service Configuration Risk
/ConfigRisk/Service.description: Network services such as SSH and FTP have insecure configurations, including unrestricted connection IPs and methods, and no maximum login attempts set. The assets at risk are within the internal network (destination address).

/ConfigRisk/MidWare.label: Middleware Configuration Risk
/ConfigRisk/MidWare.description: The middleware lacks secure configuration, which may lead to data leakage, server compromise, and other hazards. The at-risk assets are located in the internal network (destination address).

/ConfigRisk/DeviceConf.label: Device Configuration Risk
/ConfigRisk/DeviceConf.description: The device lacks proper security configurations, which may lead to data leakage, server compromise, and other hazards. The at-risk assets are located in the internal network (destination address).

/ConfigRisk/Database.label: Database Configuration Risk
/ConfigRisk/Database.description: Improper database configuration may lead to data leakage, server compromise, and other hazards. The at-risk assets are located in the internal network (destination address).

/ConfigRisk/ClearTextCredit.label: Clear Text Credit Transmission Risk
/ConfigRisk/ClearTextCredit.description: Sensitive information is transmitted without encryption during data transfer. Sensitive information includes passwords, cryptographic keys, certificates, session identifiers, private data (such as message content), authorization credentials, personal data, as well as program files, configuration files, log files, backup files, etc. The assets at risk are within the internal network (destination address).

/Audit/IllegalOp.label: Audit Illegal Operation
/Audit/IllegalOp.description: Includes alerts for various unauthorized operations within the internal network, such as: 1. Unknown devices connecting to the network, non-secure computers processing classified files, etc. 2. Bypassing bastion hosts to access production environments. 3. Other operations that violate laws, regulations, and company policies. No attackers or victims involved.

/Audit/IllegalAccess.label: Audit Illegal Access
/Audit/IllegalAccess.description: Internal network hosts accessing prohibited websites. Includes: 1. Content involving malicious billing, privacy theft, gambling, violence, pornography, or secessionist activities. Detailed regulations can be found at: http://report.12377.cn:13225/mainNotice.html. 2. Content violating company policies, such as gaming websites, recruitment sites, or e-commerce platforms. No attackers or victims involved.

/Audit/Exfiltration.label: Audit Exfiltration
/Audit/Exfiltration.description: Monitor the behavior of internal network hosts transmitting or sending data externally, such as: 1. Uploading files to external FTP servers. 2. Sending large email attachments to external mailboxes. 3. Synchronizing files to cloud storage. 4. Posting data to external HTTP servers, etc. Audit the behavior of data transmission rather than the content itself.

/Audit/Others.label: /Audit/Others
/Audit/Others.description: Alerts for other behavioral audit events

/AccountRisk/SuspModify.label: Account Risk Suspicious Modification
/AccountRisk/SuspModify.description: Record abnormal account change behaviors such as frequent permission modifications and frequent password changes. The alert destination address is the internal network.

/AccountRisk/SuspBehavior.label: Account Risk Suspicious Behavior
/AccountRisk/SuspBehavior.description: Alert for abnormal account behavior. Common scenarios include: Spam sending - the account sends spam emails (intranet -> SMTP server). Data theft - downloading large volumes of sensitive files (intranet -> intranet). Suspicious access - attempting to log into critical servers (intranet -> intranet). Attacker unknown, victim: the account in question.

/AccountRisk/Others.label: Account Risk Others
/AccountRisk/Others.description: Alerts for abnormal events from other accounts

/AccountRisk/BruteForce.label: Account Risk Brute Force
/AccountRisk/BruteForce.description: The attacker employs enumeration methods to systematically attempt username and password combinations for login attempts. Target of attack: user accounts. The intended victims of this type must be internal network destinations. Common brute-force attacks and weak password enumeration attempts fall under this category. Brute-force attacks initiated from internal networks against external networks are classified as: Host Anomaly/Host External Attacks.

/WebAttack/Others.label: Web Attack Others
/WebAttack/Others.description: Other types of web attack behaviors initiated by external IP addresses.

/WebAttack/InfoLeak.label: Web Attack Information Leakage
/WebAttack/InfoLeak.description: Due to misconfiguration of the web server, external attackers exploited vulnerabilities to obtain sensitive information from the server. Sensitive information includes passwords, keys, certificates, session identifiers, licenses, private data (such as SMS content), authorization credentials, personal data, as well as program files, configuration files, log files, backup files, etc. Note the distinction from lateral movement/sensitive data leakage types.

/WebAttack/BypassAccCtrl.label: Web Attack Bypass Access Control
/WebAttack/BypassAccCtrl.description: Attack behaviors initiated from external networks targeting privilege escalation vulnerabilities, including horizontal privilege escalation attempts, authentication bypass vulnerability attempts, and other similar types.

/SuspTraffic/MaliciousDomain.label: Suspicious Traffic Malicious Domain
/SuspTraffic/MaliciousDomain.description: Internal network host requests malicious domains. Malicious domains include mining domains, C2 domains, phishing domains, and: 1. Suspicious dynamic domains, e.g., 3322, org; 2. Internal network penetration proxy domains, e.g., ngrok domains; 3. Suspected DGA domains; 4. Other types of suspicious domains.

/SuspEndpoint/SuspFile.label: Suspicious File
/SuspEndpoint/SuspFile.description: Suspicious file detected on an internal network host.

/Scan/Others.label: Scan Others
/Scan/Others.description: Other types of probing and scanning attack events initiated from external networks

/Others/Others.label: Other Threat Types
/Others/Others.description: Non-attack behaviors, business-related anomalous activities, etc. Generally low-risk and difficult to characterize.

/Exploit/Others.label: Exploit Others
/Exploit/Others.description: Other types of vulnerability exploitation attack events initiated from the external network.

/DevOps/WebError.label: DevOps Web Application Error
/DevOps/WebError.description: Web application failures can be categorized into the following types, with affected risk assets located in the internal network environment (destination address): 1. Failures caused by sudden traffic surges leading to excessive server load. 2. Failures resulting from runtime errors in program source code or logical flaws in the code. 3. Failures due to service timeouts causing operational anomalies.

/DevOps/HostError.label: Host Error
/DevOps/HostError.description: Host failures can be categorized into the following types, with the affected risk assets being the internal network environment (destination address): Detected host failures caused by various reasons include: 1. System hardware issues, primarily caused by hardware devices such as SCSI cards, motherboards, RAID cards, HBA cards, network cards, and hard drives. In such cases, it is necessary to identify the specific hardware fault details and resolve the issue by replacing the hardware. 2. Peripheral hardware issues, mainly caused by network problems. In this scenario, troubleshooting and resolution should focus on host network devices and network parameters. 3. Host software issues, primarily caused by system kernel bugs, application software bugs, or driver bugs. Resolution in such cases involves upgrading the kernel, fixing program bugs, or updating drivers. 4. Host system configuration issues, mainly caused by improper system parameter settings. These can be resolved by restoring the system to default settings or disabling the firewall.

/DevOps/DeviceError.label: Device Error
/DevOps/DeviceError.description: Device failures can be categorized into the following types, with the affected risk assets being the internal network environment (destination address): A device temporarily loses its specified functionality during its lifecycle due to wear and tear or operational usage. 1. Sudden failure: A failure that occurs abruptly. The timing is random and difficult to predict, resulting in a complete loss of device functionality. 2. Degradation failure: A failure caused by the gradual degradation of device performance. The progression is slow and follows a predictable pattern, leading to partial loss of functionality.

/DevOps/DatabaseError.label: DevOps Database Error
/DevOps/DatabaseError.description: Database failures can be categorized into the following types, with the affected risk assets being the internal network environment (destination address): 1. Transaction-internal failures. 2. System failures. 3. Media failures. 4. Computer virus failures.

/ConfigRisk/HTTPServer.label: HTTP Server Configuration Risk
/ConfigRisk/HTTPServer.description: The HTTP server has enabled uncommon methods such as PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS, and TRACE, which may lead to server information leakage and content tampering. The risk asset is located in the internal network (destination address).

/Audit/OpAudit.label: Audit Operation Audit
/Audit/OpAudit.description: Includes operations requiring audit logging such as sensitive operations (e.g., permission modifications, bulk data queries) and risky operations (e.g., data deletion, system file modifications or deletions, log clearing). The audit type is set to low level by default. No attacker or victim involved.

/Audit/IllegalSoft.label: Audit Illegal Software
/Audit/IllegalSoft.description: Internal network hosts have processes or communication traffic involving non-compliant applications. This includes: 1. Applications violating national regulations: those involving malicious billing, privacy theft, gambling, pornography, or content undermining national unity. Detailed regulations can be found at: http://report.12377.cn:13225/mainNotice.html. 2. Applications violating organizational or corporate policies, such as prohibited games, instant messaging software, or stock trading applications. Audit type with default low severity level. No attacker or victim involved.

/Audit/ConfigChange.label: Audit Config Change
/Audit/ConfigChange.description: Configuration modification behavior auditing, including: modifying firewall configurations, modifying routing tables, modifying DNS server addresses, modifying server configuration parameters, etc. Audit type, default level is low. No attacker or victim involved.

/AccountRisk/SuspLogin.label: Account Risk Suspicious Login
/AccountRisk/SuspLogin.description: This category primarily includes abnormal behavior audits such as: unusual login locations, abnormal login times, suspicious login accounts, and anomalous login outcomes. The source addresses of alerts do not distinguish between internal and external networks, while the destination addresses are internal. By default, abnormal login attempts from internal networks to external networks do not trigger alerts. If related alerts occur, they should be classified under: Host Anomalies/Others.

/SuspEndpoint/FilelessAttack.label: Suspicious Endpoint Fileless Attack
/SuspEndpoint/FilelessAttack.description: No files were created on the intranet host discovery system, but code was executed or system settings were modified. This may indicate a fileless attack, where the attacker directly executes malicious code in memory.

/Malware/Worm.label: Malware Worm
/Malware/Worm.description: Detected network worm communication activities from internal hosts.

/Malware/Trojan.label: Malware Trojan
/Malware/Trojan.description: Detected Trojan horse communication activities from internal network hosts.

/Malware/Bot.label: Malware Bot
/Malware/Bot.description: Malicious files, processes, or communications related to zombie viruses were detected on internal network hosts.

/Malware/Spyware.label: Malware Spyware
/Malware/Spyware.description: Communication signatures of spyware have been detected in the internal network host traffic.

/Malware/Backdoor.label: Malware Backdoor
/Malware/Backdoor.description: Suspected backdoor program communication characteristics detected in the internal network host communication traffic.

/Malware/Virus.label: Malware Virus
/Malware/Virus.description: An internal network host is infected with a contagious virus. This virus can infect executable files, document files, etc., causing each infected file to contain the virus code.

/Malware/MacroVirus.label: Malware Macro Virus
/Malware/MacroVirus.description: An internal network host is infected with a macro virus. This type of virus spreads by exploiting macro functionalities in document editing software, such as VBA macros in Microsoft Office.

/Malware/VirusGenerator.label: Malware Virus Generator
/Malware/VirusGenerator.description: An internal network host contains a virus generator. This is a tool used to generate or create new viruses, which may include functionality for producing custom virus code.

/Malware/TrojanDropper.label: Malware Trojan Dropper
/Malware/TrojanDropper.description: An internal network host contains a Trojan dropper. This type of program does not inherently contain malicious code, but its purpose is to release and activate other Trojan programs.

/Malware/Fileless.label: Fileless Malware
/Malware/Fileless.description: An internal network host contains a fileless malware.

/Malware/RootkitBootkit.label: Malware Rootkit Bootkit
/Malware/RootkitBootkit.description: Rootkit and Bootkit are both types of malware designed to conceal traces of malicious activities within a system, making them difficult to detect and remove. Rootkits typically embed themselves into the operating system kernel or system files to hide malicious processes, files, and registry entries. Bootkits, on the other hand, infiltrate the system's boot process to load and execute malicious code during system startup.

/Malware/Downloader.label: Malware Downloader
/Malware/Downloader.description: An internal network host is infected with a trojan downloader. This type of malware downloads and installs other malicious software onto the compromised system.

/Malware/CheatProgram.label: Malware Cheat Program
/Malware/CheatProgram.description: An internal network host is running cheat programs. These are tools designed for games or other software, but they may be maliciously exploited to obtain sensitive information or gain control of the target system.

/Malware/Prank.label: Malware Prank
/Malware/Prank.description: An internal network host contains a prank program. Such programs do not cause severe damage to the system but may perform prank behaviors such as changing the desktop background or playing sounds.

/Malware/Keylogger.label: Malware Keylogger
/Malware/Keylogger.description: An internal network host has been infected with a keylogger. This is a type of malware specifically designed to record user keystrokes, used to steal passwords and other sensitive information.

/Malware/BrowserHijacker.label: Malware Browser Hijacker
/Malware/BrowserHijacker.description: An internal network host is experiencing browser hijacking. This is used to alter user's browser settings, such as search pages and homepages, typically for targeted advertising or malicious traffic redirection.

/Malware/PenetrationTool.label: Penetration Tool
/Malware/PenetrationTool.description: Internal network hosts contain penetration tools that are being maliciously exploited. These tools are intended for security testing or penetration testing purposes, but may be illegally used to attack systems.

/Malware/HackTool.label: Malware Hack Tool
/Malware/HackTool.description: An internal network host contains hacking tools. These are tools designed for hackers to infiltrate systems, steal information, or perform other malicious activities.

/Malware/Exploit.label: Malware Exploit
/Malware/Exploit.description: An internal network host contains malicious exploitation tools. These are specialized tools designed to exploit known system or software vulnerabilities to perform unauthorized operations.

/Malware/VirTool.label: Malware VirTool
/Malware/VirTool.description: An internal network host contains a code obfuscation tool. This is a tool used to obfuscate software code, making it difficult to understand and reverse engineer, typically employed to conceal the true intent of malware.

/Phishing/EmailPhishing.label: Phishing Email
/Phishing/EmailPhishing.description: By sending emails disguised as legitimate sources, the recipient is induced to click on malicious links or provide personal information, in order to steal sensitive data or carry out malicious attacks.

/Phishing/SocialMediaPhishing.label: Phishing Social Media Phishing
/Phishing/SocialMediaPhishing.description: Phishing attacks conducted via social media platforms by impersonating trusted individuals or organizations, sending links or files to deceive users into performing actions.

/Phishing/WebPhishing.label: Phishing Web Phishing
/Phishing/WebPhishing.description: Creating deceptive websites that mimic the appearance of legitimate sites to trick users into entering personal information, such as login credentials or credit card details.

/Phishing/Others.label: Phishing Others
/Phishing/Others.description: Including but not limited to email phishing, social media phishing, website phishing, and other phishing attacks conducted through various communication channels.

/Exploit/RemoteService.label: Exploit Remote Service
/Exploit/RemoteService.description: Vulnerability scanning and attack attempts targeting remote services on the network (such as remote desktop, databases, file sharing, etc.), with the aim of exploiting weaknesses in the services to gain control of the target system.

/WebAttack/FileRead.label: Web Attack File Read
/WebAttack/FileRead.description: Attackers access files on the server, potentially obtaining sensitive information, executing arbitrary commands, or compromising the system.

/WebAttack/WebshellUpload.label: Web Attack Webshell Upload
/WebAttack/WebshellUpload.description: The attacker attempted to upload a webshell backdoor file to gain control of the target server.

/Credential/PTH.label: Credential Pass The Hash
/Credential/PTH.description: Attackers gain access to other machines in a Windows network by obtaining users' NTLM or LM hashes without requiring plaintext passwords. This method exploits the pass-the-hash mechanism in Windows domain environments, allowing attackers to access protected resources without needing the user's actual password.

/Credential/PTK.label: Credential PTK
/Credential/PTK.description: The attacker obtains the user's encryption key and uses it to encrypt data sent to the system, leveraging this key to access restricted resources and perform sensitive operations.

/Credential/PTT.label: Credential Pass The Ticket
/Credential/PTT.description: The attacker obtains or steals tickets used for authentication in the Kerberos system, then uses these tickets to access network resources on behalf of legitimate users.

/Credential/TokenHijacking.label: Credential Token Hijacking
/Credential/TokenHijacking.description: The attacker intercepts or copies network tokens used for authentication (such as OAuth tokens, JWT tokens, etc.), then uses these tokens to impersonate legitimate users and perform actions.

/Credential/Forgery.label: Credential Forgery
/Credential/Forgery.description: Attackers create or modify credentials, such as usernames and passwords, digital certificates, tokens, etc., to gain unauthorized access to systems or network resources without legitimate user authorization.

/Credential/Steal.label: Credential Theft
/Credential/Steal.description: Attackers obtain user login credentials through various means (such as keyloggers, phishing attacks, social engineering, etc.) and then use these credentials to access the system.

/MITM/WLANHijacking.label: MITM WLAN Hijacking
/MITM/WLANHijacking.description: A network behavior that exploits security vulnerabilities such as application flaws, protocol weaknesses, and configuration errors to hijack WiFi traffic. For example, after hijacking WiFi, it can display vulgar advertisements and illegal content, or cause widespread network outages within the WiFi coverage area.

/MITM/TrafficHijacking.label: MITM Traffic Hijacking
/MITM/TrafficHijacking.description: Attackers illegally intercept and manipulate network traffic to obtain sensitive information or gain control over network resources.

/MITM/BGPHijackingAttack.label: BGP Hijacking Attack
/MITM/BGPHijackingAttack.description: Manipulating Internet routing paths by maliciously announcing BGP routes to achieve certain objectives, such as misleading and intercepting traffic or modifying data. A common attack method involves broadcasting announcements with false prefixes, causing the compromised router to further contaminate routing information on other routers, potentially even propagating to the backbone Internet.

/DataSteal/DatabaseDump.label: Data Exfiltration Database Dump
/DataSteal/DatabaseDump.description: Migrate or copy data from one database to another, typically by downloading database files using database operation and maintenance tools.

/DataSteal/DataDrip.label: Data Exfiltration
/DataSteal/DataDrip.description: Retrieve specified type of data in small batches over an extended period, with the total data volume reaching a certain threshold.

/DataSteal/APICrawling.label: API Data Crawling
/DataSteal/APICrawling.description: When the number of API accesses by a subject entity within a unit time exceeds the threshold, and the deduplicated count of returned data results of a specified type surpasses a certain threshold.

/DataMisuse/Abroad.label: Data Transfer Abroad
/DataMisuse/Abroad.description: Access to domestic data from overseas addresses, or active transmission of data from domestic addresses to overseas destinations.

/DataMisuse/OutDomain.label: /Datamisuse/Outdomain
/DataMisuse/OutDomain.description: Data flows from an internal trusted domain to an external untrusted domain.

/DataMisuse/IllegalDataCollect.label: Data Misuse Illegal Data Collection
/DataMisuse/IllegalDataCollect.description: Risk alert for violations of personal information regulatory policies or standards, indicating potential illegal or non-compliant collection of personal information.

/DataMisuse/GovAudit.label: Data Misuse Government Audit
/DataMisuse/GovAudit.description: For specific systems in the healthcare industry, the unauthorized acquisition of specific data by organizational entities without permission.

/DataMisuse/IllegalDataUse.label: Data Misuse / Illegal Data Use
/DataMisuse/IllegalDataUse.description: Violation of laws, administrative regulations, or other relevant provisions by illegally or improperly performing data handling operations.

/ConfigRisk/Exploit.label: Exploit Risk
/ConfigRisk/Exploit.description: The server has not undergone timely patch updates or security configurations, resulting in the risk of vulnerability exploitation.

/SuspTraffic/AccessAnomaly.label: Suspicious Traffic Access Anomaly
/SuspTraffic/AccessAnomaly.description: Intranet host detection alerts for abnormal user access behavior: user access behavior deviates from the normal baseline, or abnormal domain/service access is detected.

/SuspTraffic/TrafficAnomaly.label: Suspicious Traffic Anomaly
/SuspTraffic/TrafficAnomaly.description: Intranet host detection traffic anomaly alert: Network traffic deviates from the normal baseline.

/SuspEndpoint/SuspCommand.label: Suspicious Command
/SuspEndpoint/SuspCommand.description: Intranet host detected suspicious command alerts. Includes: 1. User executed unauthorized or abnormal commands. 2. Frequent execution of specific commands within a short period, which may indicate automated attacks.

/SuspEndpoint/SuspiciousSpread.label: Suspicious Endpoint Spread
/SuspEndpoint/SuspiciousSpread.description: Intranet hosts spread suspicious code through shared folders, removable media, remote copying, and other means.

/SuspEndpoint/WMI.label: Suspicious Endpoint WMI Exploitation
/SuspEndpoint/WMI.description: Intranet host detection WMI exploitation alert. Unauthorized operations were executed using Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI), potentially for information gathering or remote control purposes.

/SuspEndpoint/ProcessInjection.label: Suspicious Endpoint Process Injection
/SuspEndpoint/ProcessInjection.description: Intranet host detected abnormal process injection alert. Malicious code was injected into the process, causing it to share address space with legitimate processes.

/SuspEndpoint/InformationGathering.label: Suspicious Endpoint Information Gathering
/SuspEndpoint/InformationGathering.description: An internal network host detected abnormal local information collection behavior. This may indicate an attacker gathering local system information, such as user lists and system configurations.

/SuspEndpoint/DefenseEvasion.label: Suspicious Endpoint Defense Evasion
/SuspEndpoint/DefenseEvasion.description: Intranet host discovery involves attempts to bypass detection by uninstalling/disabling security software, obfuscating/encrypting data and scripts, or abusing trusted processes to conceal and disguise their malware.

/SuspEndpoint/ReverseShell.label: Suspected Endpoint Reverse Shell
/SuspEndpoint/ReverseShell.description: The intranet host discovery system detected abnormal communication between internal processes and external IPs, which may indicate that attackers are remotely controlling compromised hosts through reverse shell techniques.

/SuspEndpoint/Persistence.label: Suspicious Endpoint Persistence
/SuspEndpoint/Persistence.description: Intranet host discovery persistence mechanisms, such as service creation, registry modifications, and file system alterations, which may be employed to ensure long-term attacker presence on the system.

/SuspEndpoint/PrivilegeEscalation.label: Suspected Endpoint Privilege Escalation
/SuspEndpoint/PrivilegeEscalation.description: An internal network host detected user account attempts or successful privilege escalation, which may indicate that an attacker is attempting to gain higher system access privileges to conduct broader attacks.

/SuspEndpoint/RemoteService.label: Suspicious Endpoint Remote Service Exploitation
/SuspEndpoint/RemoteService.description: An unknown remote service is detected running on an internal host, which may contain known vulnerabilities that could be exploited by attackers to perform remote code execution.

/SuspEndpoint/RemoteExec.label: Suspicious Endpoint Remote Execution
/SuspEndpoint/RemoteExec.description: An internal network host discovery system detected attempts to use remote execution tools or malicious exploitation of remote services to execute unauthorized commands or scripts.

/SuspEndpoint/TraceEradication.label: Suspicious Endpoint Trace Eradication
/SuspEndpoint/TraceEradication.description: Signs of deletion, modification, or concealment of log files, system files, or trace cleaning tools detected on the intranet host discovery system, which may indicate that attackers are attempting to conceal their activities.

/AccountRisk/SuspAccount.label: Suspicious Account
/AccountRisk/SuspAccount.description: Suspicious accounts refer to accounts that may be used to conceal attacker activities, achieve persistent access, or perform unauthorized operations. These include: backdoor accounts, hidden accounts, shadow accounts, etc.

/Malware/MaliciousScript.label: Malware Malicious Script
/Malware/MaliciousScript.description: Internal network hosts running scripts with malicious behavior characteristics, such as enabling PowerShell or modifying registry entries.

/Malware/MaliciousAdware.label: Malware Malicious Adware
/Malware/MaliciousAdware.description: Malvertising refers to malicious content published through online advertising platforms with the intent to deceive or lure users. These ads may redirect users to malicious websites, download malware, or expose personal sensitive information.

/WebAttack/FileWrite.label: Web Attack File Write
/WebAttack/FileWrite.description: Attackers exploit vulnerabilities in systems or applications to illegally write malicious files or implant malicious code. They may use file writing behaviors to achieve system intrusion, privilege escalation, or execution of malicious operations.

/WebAttack/FileDownload.label: Web Attack File Download
/WebAttack/FileDownload.description: Attackers exploit vulnerabilities in systems or applications to illegally download sensitive or malicious files from target systems. Through file download activities, attackers may obtain system information, steal user data, or distribute malware.

/WebAttack/FileParsingVul.label: Web Attack File Parsing Vulnerability
/WebAttack/FileParsingVul.description: A vulnerability was identified in middleware (such as IIS, Apache, Nginx, etc.) during file parsing, which attackers could exploit to achieve unauthorized file parsing.

/WebAttack/Hotlinking.label: Web Attack Hotlinking
/WebAttack/Hotlinking.description: The attacker exploits resources of the target website by referencing them on external sites, resulting in unauthorized usage or depletion of the target website's resources.

/Scan/NetworkScan.label: Network Scan
/Scan/NetworkScan.description: Network scanning refers to the process of scanning all devices and systems on a network to obtain information such as network topology, device status, and open ports. It is commonly used for security audits, asset management, and vulnerability detection to identify potential security risks and optimize network configurations.

/Scan/SystemScan.label: System Scan
/Scan/SystemScan.description: System scanning refers to the process of conducting comprehensive inspection and analysis of computer systems to detect vulnerabilities, malware, configuration errors, and other potential security issues. Through system scanning, security risks can be identified and remediated to ensure system stability and security.

/WebAttack/MemoryShell.label: Web Attack Memory Shell
/WebAttack/MemoryShell.description: Memory-resident malware (memory horse) attack refers to a technique where attackers inject malicious code into the target system's memory to create a persistent malicious program that resides in memory, enabling long-term control of the system. Memory horse attacks are typically difficult to detect through traditional file system scanning and antivirus software since they leave no traces on disk. This attack method is commonly used in cyberattacks to steal sensitive information, execute remote control, or disrupt system functionality.

/DataTampering/FileTampering.label: Data Tampering File Tampering
/DataTampering/FileTampering.description: File tampering refers to the unauthorized modification, deletion, or destruction of file content by attackers. Such attacks may result in data corruption, information leakage, or system instability.

/DataSteal/DatabaseConnect.label: Data Exfiltration Database Connection
/DataSteal/DatabaseConnect.description: Database connection theft refers to the malicious activity where attackers obtain database connection credentials to gain unauthorized access to databases, enabling them to steal sensitive data or perform unauthorized operations.

/DataSteal/UnauthorizedAccess.label: Unauthorized Access
/DataSteal/UnauthorizedAccess.description: Unauthorized access refers to the act of an attacker illegally accessing systems or data without proper authorization, typically with the intent to steal or destroy data.

/SuspTraffic/RemoteService.label: Suspicious Traffic Remote Service
/SuspTraffic/RemoteService.description: Remote service abnormal traffic refers to anomalous or suspicious network traffic detected during remote service connections, which may indicate unauthorized access attempts, data breaches, or other malicious activities.

/SuspTraffic/SuspProtocol.label: Suspicious Traffic Protocol Anomaly
/SuspTraffic/SuspProtocol.description: Suspicious protocol traffic refers to the detection of traffic using uncommon or anomalous network protocols, which may indicate potential security threats such as malicious activities or unauthorized communications.

/SuspEndpoint/CommandAndControl.label: Suspected Endpoint Command And Control
/SuspEndpoint/CommandAndControl.description: Command and Control (C2) refers to the behavior where attackers remotely issue instructions and manage compromised devices, typically used to coordinate malicious activities such as data theft, network attacks, or malware propagation.

attackerAddress.label: Attacker IP Address
attackerAddress.description: The source IP address of the attacker initiating the threat attack.

victimAddress.label: Victim IP Address
victimAddress.description: IP address that has been subjected to threat attacks or affected by risks

confidence.label: Confidence Level
confidence.description: An evaluation metric indicating the level of confidence in the accuracy of threat detection, attribution, or analysis results.

Low.label: Low Confidence Level
Low.description: The alert is based on a single, uncertain indicator and may potentially be a false positive, requiring further verification.

Medium.label: Medium Confidence
Medium.description: The alert information has a certain degree of reliability but still requires analysis and verification.

High.label: High Confidence
High.description: The false positive rate of the alert information is extremely low, with high credibility.

killChain.label: Kill Chain
killChain.description: Describes the phase of the attack behavior within the attack lifecycle.

KC_Reconnaissance.label: Reconnaissance
KC_Reconnaissance.description: The process where cyber attackers select targets, conduct initial penetration attempts, and seek to discover information about the system's version, architecture, and vulnerabilities. This phase may involve various methods such as web service scanning and probing of open ports on hosts. Typically, attacks at this stage exhibit numerous similar behaviors, with most attempts ending in failure.

KC_Delivery.label: Delivery
KC_Delivery.description: The stage where the compromised device receives or becomes infected with malicious programs, phishing emails, and hacker tools. The delivery process can be active, such as end-users voluntarily downloading malicious programs from the internet or receiving phishing email attachments, or passive, such as attackers exploiting open service interfaces to upload trojans, backdoors, remote control programs, etc. This enables the attacker to successfully gain control over the victim device.

KC_Exploitation.label: Exploitation
KC_Exploitation.description: After obtaining basic information about the target, cyber attackers attempt to exploit potential vulnerabilities or weaknesses to conduct targeted penetration attacks. The exploitation process may succeed or fail (e.g., being blocked by firewalls, IPS devices, or endpoint antivirus programs).

KC_CommandControl.label: Command And Control
KC_CommandControl.description: Cyber attackers exploit implanted backdoors or malicious programs to remotely control victim devices. During this process, attackers may send commands to activate or manipulate backdoors on the compromised host to execute relevant operations. Alternatively, programs running on the victim device may actively initiate callback requests to transmit information data to the hacker. Typically, alerts at this stage indicate that the targeted system may have already been compromised.

KC_InternalRecon.label: Internal Reconnaissance
KC_InternalRecon.description: The attacker successfully gains access to the target network system through certain means (such as stealing VPN credentials, brute-forcing remote control interfaces, etc.) and proceeds to conduct service probing and information gathering within the target network. This process may also involve the hacker obtaining permissions on internal devices and remotely controlling them.

KC_LateralMov.label: Lateral Movement
KC_LateralMov.description: When a device within the information system is compromised, or after hackers steal login credentials, attackers conduct lateral movement within the internal system to attempt gaining more device privileges. This process primarily involves internal-to-internal vulnerability exploitation and sensitive operations. Typically, alerts at this stage indicate that the targeted system may already be compromised.

KC_Profit.label: KC Profit
KC_Profit.description: After successfully implanting malicious programs into the target, the attacker takes specific actions to achieve their objectives, such as encrypting files on the target host device with malicious intent, stealing and destroying data, or utilizing device resources for cryptocurrency mining. Typically, alerts at this stage indicate that the targeted system may have already been compromised.

KC_Others.label: KC Others
KC_Others.description: Non-attack behaviors, such as misconfigurations, device failures, etc.

techniqueId.label: Technique ID
techniqueId.description: The unique identifier of the specific attack technique in the MITRE ATT&CK framework corresponding to the attack behavior.

techniqueName.label: Technique Name
techniqueName.description: The name of the specific attack technique in the MITRE ATT&CK framework corresponding to the attack behavior.

subTechniqueId.label: Sub Technique ID
subTechniqueId.description: The unique identifier of the specific attack sub-technique corresponding to the attack behavior in the MITRE ATT&CK framework.

subTechniqueName.label: Sub Technique Name
subTechniqueName.description: The name of the specific attack sub-technique corresponding to the attack behavior in the MITRE ATT&CK framework.

suggestion.label: Remediation Recommendation
suggestion.description: Standardized response and remediation guidance provided for threat attacks.

virusName.label: Virus Name
virusName.description: Virus description name, used for virus identification

dhcpAddress.label: DHCP Assigned IP Address
dhcpAddress.description: IP address dynamically assigned by the DHCP server

failReason.label: Failure Reason
failReason.description: Detailed technical reasons and contextual information for the failed operation

srcUserName.label: Source User Name
srcUserName.description: The principal user identity name that initiates network connections, system access, or security events.

relateUserName.label: Related User Name
relateUserName.description: Auxiliary username information associated with the primary operator's username.

relateAddress.label: Related IP Address
relateAddress.description: Auxiliary IP address information associated with the primary operator user, used to record network address information in layer 3 association scenarios. For example, in database audit scenarios involving web-database separation, this field can be used to associate the network address when a user logs into the web server.

relateInfo.label: Related Information
relateInfo.description: Descriptive information associated with the primary operator's username.

dbType.label: Database Type
dbType.description: The type of database management system (DBMS) used for identification.

requestHeader.label: Request Header
requestHeader.description: HTTP headers are used by clients to transmit additional information, client characteristics, authentication metadata, and other request-related data to the server when making network requests.

srcHostName.label: Source Host Name
srcHostName.description: The hostname of the initiator in network connections or threat attacks. This could be a NetBIOS name, DNS hostname, or locally configured machine name.

srcAddress.label: Source IP Address
srcAddress.description: The IP address corresponding to the initiator of the network connection.

tiSubcategory.label: Threat Intelligence Subcategory
tiSubcategory.description: Sub-category of threat intelligence IOC (Indicator of Compromise).

/WhiteList/Others.label: Whitelist Others
/WhiteList/Others.description: Whitelist identifier for trusted entities and resources, used to reduce false positives.

/C2/Sinkhole.label: C2 Sinkhole
/C2/Sinkhole.description: Command and Control (C&C) server taken over by security agencies, used for threat research and monitoring.

/C2/Trojan.label: C2 Trojan
/C2/Trojan.description: Command and control (C2) communication of Trojan malware, used for remotely controlling infected systems.

/C2/Virus.label: C2 Virus Malware
/C2/Virus.description: Command and control communication of computer viruses, with self-replicating capability.

/C2/Worm.label: C2 Worm
/C2/Worm.description: Command and control communication of network worms, spreading infection through network propagation.

/C2/Ransomware.label: C2 Ransomware
/C2/Ransomware.description: Ransomware command and control (C2) communication, used for data encryption and ransom payment.

/C2/Backdoor.label: C2 Backdoor
/C2/Backdoor.description: Backdoor command and control communication, providing unauthorized system access

/C2/PasswordSteal.label: C2 Password Theft Malware
/C2/PasswordSteal.description: Command and control communication of password-stealing malware, used for credential harvesting.

/C2/DDoS.label: C2 DDoS Malicious File Callback
/C2/DDoS.description: Command and control (C&C) communication of DDoS botnets, used for distributed denial-of-service attacks.

/C2/KeyLogger.label: C2 Key Logger
/C2/KeyLogger.description: Keylogger command and control communication, used for capturing user input.

/C2/Rootkit.label: C2 Rootkit
/C2/Rootkit.description: Rootkit command and control communication, used to conceal malicious activities.

/C2/Spyware.label: C2 Spyware
/C2/Spyware.description: Command and control communication of spyware, used for intelligence gathering and surveillance.

/C2/Others.label: C2 Others
/C2/Others.description: Other types of command and control server communications

/Malware/Miner.label: Malware Miner
/Malware/Miner.description: Cryptocurrency mining malware's communication with mining pools

/Malware/Others.label: Malware Others
/Malware/Others.description: Other types of malicious software domain connection activities

/PUA/ADHost.label: PUA Ad Host
/PUA/ADHost.description: Network addresses of adware and related tracking services

/PUA/Gambling.label: Potentially Unwanted Application Gambling
/PUA/Gambling.description: Online gambling and related fraudulent activity network addresses

/PUA/Porn.label: PUA Porn
/PUA/Porn.description: Adult content and potentially malicious network addresses

/PUA/HackTool.label: Potentially Unwanted Application Hack Tool
/PUA/HackTool.description: Network connections related to hacking tools and attack frameworks

/PUA/MonitoringTool.label: PUA Monitoring Tool
/PUA/MonitoringTool.description: Monitoring and surveillance of network communication activities by software

/PUA/Others.label: PUA Others Unwanted Address Connection
/PUA/Others.description: Unnecessary application network connections that may be present

/Exploit/WebExploit.label: Web Exploit
/Exploit/WebExploit.description: Attack exploitation activities targeting web application vulnerabilities

/Exploit/HostExploit.label: Host Exploit
/Exploit/HostExploit.description: Exploitation targeting vulnerabilities in operating systems and host software.

/Exploit/Others.label: Exploit Others
/Exploit/Others.description: Other types of vulnerability exploitation and attack activities

/Spam/Email.label: Spam Email
/Spam/Email.description: Spam sending sources and related infrastructure

/Spam/Message.label: Spam Message
/Spam/Message.description: Instant messaging and social media spam sources

/Spam/Others.label: Spam Others
/Spam/Others.description: Sources of other types of spam and harassment content

/Suspicious/DGA.label: Suspicious DGA Domain
/Suspicious/DGA.description: Malicious domains generated by Domain Generation Algorithm (DGA)

/Suspicious/Others.label: Suspicious Address
/Suspicious/Others.description: Other suspicious and potentially malicious network addresses

/BruteForce/Services.label: Brute Force Services
/BruteForce/Services.description: Brute-force attack source targeting network services

/BruteForce/HTTP.label: HTTP Brute Force
/BruteForce/HTTP.description: Brute force attack against web applications via HTTP protocol

/BruteForce/Credenti.label: Brute Force Credential Attack
/BruteForce/Credenti.description: Source address conducting credential stuffing attacks using leaked credentials

/BruteForce/Others.label: Brute Force Others
/BruteForce/Others.description: Other types of brute force and credential stuffing attacks

/Phishing/Others.label: Phishing URL
/Phishing/Others.description: Phishing attacks and fraudulent website URLs

/Scanner/Others.label: Scanner Address
/Scanner/Others.description: Source address of network scanning and reconnaissance activities

/Spider/Others.label: Spider Address
/Spider/Others.description: Web crawlers and automated content scraping activities

/Compromised/Others.label: Compromised Host
/Compromised/Others.description: Compromised and controlled puppet hosts and zombie nodes

/Info/IDC.label: IDC Server
/Info/IDC.description: Internet Data Center server and hosting services

/Info/Bogon.label: Reserved IP Address
/Info/Bogon.description: Unallocated and reserved IP address space

/Info/DNS.label: DNS Server
/Info/DNS.description: Domain Name System (DNS) server and resolution service

/Info/DDNS.label: Dynamic DNS
/Info/DDNS.description: Dynamic Domain Name System (DDNS) service address

/Info/CDN.label: CDN Server
/Info/CDN.description: Content Delivery Network (CDN) servers and edge nodes

/Info/SEC.label: Search Engine Crawler Address
/Info/SEC.description: Search engine crawler and indexing service addresses

/Info/EDU.label: Education Network
/Info/EDU.description: Educational institutions and academic network addresses

/Info/BTTracker.label: BitTorrent Tracker
/Info/BTTracker.description: BitTorrent trackers and P2P file sharing services

/Info/Tor.label: Tor Network Address
/Info/Tor.description: Tor anonymous network nodes and exit relays

/Info/Proxy.label: Proxy Address
/Info/Proxy.description: Proxy servers and anonymous access services

/Info/VPN.label: VPN Address
/Info/VPN.description: Virtual Private Network (VPN) service and egress nodes

/Info/Others.label: Other Information Intelligence
/Info/Others.description: Other information type threat intelligence identifier

/Others/Others.label: Other Unknown Intelligence
/Others/Others.description: Unclassified and other types of threat intelligence

responseBody.label: Response Body
responseBody.description: The response content received by the client in an HTTP network request.

srcTransPort.label: Source Translated Port
srcTransPort.description: Records the mapped source port number after Network Address Translation (NAT).

destTransAddress.label: Destination Translated Address
destTransAddress.description: Records the destination IP address after Network Address Translation (NAT) mapping.

destTransPort.label: Destination Translated Port
destTransPort.description: Records the destination port number after Network Address Translation (NAT) mapping.

IoC.label: Indicator of Compromise
IoC.description: Specific indicators or signatures used to identify and detect cybersecurity threats, including hash values of malicious files, suspicious network addresses, suspicious domain names, etc.

responseHeader.label: Response Header
responseHeader.description: Metadata returned by the server to the client in an HTTP network response, describing the response (such as content type, length) and server information.

passwd.label: Password
passwd.description: A set of secret characters used by the user to verify identity or access permissions.

requestBody.label: HTTP Request Body
requestBody.description: The data content transmitted by the HTTP network request client when sending requests to the server, typically including request parameters, form data, or JSON payload.

requestCookies.label: Request Cookies
requestCookies.description: Small text files sent from a web server to a browser and stored, used to identify user identity or record status in subsequent requests.

responseAddress.label: Response IP Address
responseAddress.description: The IP address information returned in the DNS query response.

requestUrlQuery.label: Request URI Query
requestUrlQuery.description: The portion of the HTTP request URL starting from the root '/' to the end of the query string.

url.label: URL
url.description: Uniform Resource Locator (URL) used for malware distribution, phishing attacks, or command and control servers.

ip.label: IP Address
ip.description: IPv4 or IPv6 addresses associated with malicious activities, commonly used for command and control servers or attack source identification.

file.label: File Hash
file.description: Cryptographic hash values of malware or suspicious files, including algorithms such as MD5, SHA1, and SHA256.

email.label: Email Address
email.description: Email addresses used in phishing, spam, or social engineering attacks.

domain.label: Domain Name
domain.description: Domain names used for malware command and control, phishing, or fraudulent activities.

/WhiteList.label: White List
/WhiteList.description: Trusted entity or indicator list, used to reduce false positives and exclude legitimate traffic.

/C2.label: C2 Address
/C2.description: Command and Control server address, the control channel through which malware communicates with attackers.

/Malware.label: Malicious Communication Address
/Malware.description: Communication addresses associated with malware, including download or update servers for viruses, worms, ransomware, etc.

/PUA.label: Potentially Unwanted Address
/PUA.description: Potentially unwanted application-related addresses, which, while not malicious, may pose privacy or security risks.

/Exploit.label: Exploit
/Exploit.description: Address related to exploit tools or attack code, used for software vulnerability exploitation and privilege escalation.

/Spam.label: Spam
/Spam.description: Spam or junk message source address, sending unsolicited bulk commercial or malicious messages.

/Suspicious.label: Suspicious Intelligence
/Suspicious.description: Indicators of anomalous behavior or potential threats that require further security analysis and investigation.

/BruteForce.label: Brute Force
/BruteForce.description: Brute force attack source address, systematically attempting to guess authentication credentials and passwords.

/Phishing.label: Phishing URL
/Phishing.description: Phishing website or email server address that masquerades as a trusted entity to deceive users into divulging sensitive information.

/Scanner.label: Scanner Address
/Scanner.description: Source address of network scanning activity, probing for network vulnerabilities, open ports, and service information.

/Spider.label: Spider Address
/Spider.description: Web crawler or bot address that automatically scrapes web content, potentially used for information gathering.

/Compromised.label: Compromised System
/Compromised.description: Compromised host address, controlled by attackers to launch further attacks.

/Info.label: Information Intelligence
/Info.description: Contextual information threat intelligence, including attack organizations, tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs).

/Others.label: Other Intelligence
/Others.description: Other types of threat intelligence indicators that do not fall into the above standard categories.

requestMethod.label: Request Method
requestMethod.description: The request type used by the network client when sending requests to the server, such as standard methods like GET, POST, etc., uniformly represented in uppercase letters.

mailType.label: Mail Type
mailType.description: Identifies the format type of the email content.

text.label: Plain Text
text.description: The email content is in plain text format.

html.label: HTML
html.description: The email content is in HTML format and may contain rich text and scripts.

multipart.label: Multipart Format
multipart.description: The email content consists of multiple parts, such as text, HTML, and attachments.

others.label: Other Formats
others.description: Other email content formats, such as rich text format, etc.

regNewName.label: Registry New Key Name
regNewName.description: Modified registry key name in registry operation events

connectCount.label: Connection Count
connectCount.description: Count the total number of currently active network connection sessions.

rstCount.label: RST Packet Count
rstCount.description: Count of reset (RST) packets received or sent in TCP connections.

finCount.label: FIN Packet Count
finCount.description: Count the number of Finish (FIN) packets sent during the normal termination of a TCP connection.

synCount.label: SYN Packet Count
synCount.description: Count the number of synchronization (SYN) packets sent during the TCP three-way handshake process.

peakPackagesRate.label: Peak Packet Rate
peakPackagesRate.description: Records the maximum packet processing rate of a network interface or system during a specific time period, measured in packets per second (pps).

flowPackets.label: Flow Packets
flowPackets.description: The cumulative count of data packets transmitted within a network session or time window.

bytesCount.label: Bytes Count
bytesCount.description: Accumulated byte count transmitted within network sessions or a specified time window.

dropPackagesRate.label: Packet Drop Rate
dropPackagesRate.description: The rate of data packets lost during network transmission.

processUserName.label: Process User Name
processUserName.description: Operating system user account of the executing process

pktsIn.label: Packets In
pktsIn.description: Total count of inbound packets received by the network interface or session.

pktsOut.label: Packets Out
pktsOut.description: Total count of outbound packets transmitted by a network interface or session.

IoCLevel.label: IoC Threat Level
IoCLevel.description: Threat level assessment rating of the intelligence IOC (Indicator of Compromise)

Medium.label: Medium
Medium.description: Medium threat level, associated with known malicious activities, requires attention and monitoring.

Low.label: Low
Low.description: Low threat level, suspicious but with limited risk. Recommended actions include monitoring and logging.

Info.label: Information
Info.description: Information level, used solely for reference and contextual analysis, does not pose a direct threat.

High.label: High
High.description: High threat level, strongly correlated with active attack activities, requiring immediate investigation and response.

Critical.label: Critical
Critical.description: Critical threat level, confirmed malicious activity requiring immediate response and containment.

threatActorOrgId.label: Threat Actor Organization ID
threatActorOrgId.description: Unique identifier of the organization or family to which the threat intelligence IOC belongs.

virusFamily.label: Virus Family
virusFamily.description: A group of viruses sharing common codebase, attack techniques, or author attribution.

fileList.label: File List
fileList.description: Record the collection of all attachment filenames in the email.

osUser.label: OS User
osUser.description: User identifier for authentication or operation execution at the operating system level

mailSubject.label: Mail Subject
mailSubject.description: The subject line content of the email, summarizing the main purpose and content overview of the email.

queryType.label: Query Type
queryType.description: Identifies the resource record type of the DNS query request

A.label: IPv4 Address Record
A.description: Host IPv4 address record, the most common type of DNS query.

AAAA.label: IPv6 Address Record
AAAA.description: Record of the host's IPv6 address, used for IPv6 network detection.

CNAME.label: CNAME
CNAME.description: Domain alias record, used for domain redirection analysis

MX.label: Mail Exchange Record
MX.description: Mail server logs, used for email infrastructure analysis

TXT.label: TXT Record
TXT.description: Textual information records, commonly used for DNS tunneling and SPF verification.

NS.label: Name Server Record
NS.description: Authoritative name server record, used for DNS infrastructure analysis.

PTR.label: PTR Record
PTR.description: Reverse DNS lookup record, used for IP-to-domain mapping.

SOA.label: Start of Authority
SOA.description: Start of Authority (SOA) record, used for DNS zone management.

SRV.label: SRV Record
SRV.description: Service location record, used for specific service discovery

ANY.label: All Record Types
ANY.description: Request all available records, commonly used for DNS reconnaissance and amplification attacks.

mailContent.label: Mail Content
mailContent.description: The main body of the email content, containing detailed information and communication content of the email.

image.label: Process Image Path
image.description: The full path of the process executable file in the file system.

requestOs.label: Request OS
requestOs.description: Identifies the operating system type and version information used by the client in network requests.

responseOs.label: Response OS
responseOs.description: Identifies the operating system type and version information disclosed in server responses.

kerberosMsgType.label: Kerberos Message Type
kerberosMsgType.description: Message types in the Kerberos protocol, used to identify various requests and responses at different stages of the authentication process.

AS_REQ.label: Authentication Service Request
AS_REQ.description: Authentication service request, where the client requests a TGT (Ticket-Granting Ticket) from the KDC (Key Distribution Center).

AS_REP.label: AS REP
AS_REP.description: KDC's response to AS-REQ, returning the encrypted TGT

TGS_REQ.label: Ticket Granting Service Request
TGS_REQ.description: Ticket Granting Service request, using TGT to request a service ticket.

TGS_REP.label: Ticket Granting Service Response
TGS_REP.description: The KDC's response to TGS-REQ, returning the service ticket.

AP_REQ.label: Application Request
AP_REQ.description: Application request, where the client presents a service ticket to the service.

AP_REP.label: Application Response
AP_REP.description: Application response, the server's verification response to AP-REQ.

KRB_SAFE.label: KRB SAFE
KRB_SAFE.description: Kerberos security message, providing integrity and verification

KRB_PRIV.label: KRB PRIV
KRB_PRIV.description: Kerberos private message, providing confidentiality protection

KRB_CRED.label: KRB Credential Message
KRB_CRED.description: Kerberos credential message, used for credential delegation.

KRB_ERROR.label: KRB Error Message
KRB_ERROR.description: Kerberos error message, returns authentication error information

timesFrom.label: Ticket Valid From Time
timesFrom.description: The effective time of the ticket, before which the ticket is unavailable.

timesTill.label: Ticket Expiration Time
timesTill.description: The absolute expiration time of a Kerberos ticket, after which the ticket will become invalid.

parentProcessUserName.label: Parent Process User Name
parentProcessUserName.description: The name of the operating system user account that executed the parent process.

parentImage.label: Parent Process Image Path
parentImage.description: The full path of the parent process executable in the file system.

commandLine.label: Command Line
commandLine.description: The complete command-line string passed when starting the process.

parentCommandLine.label: Parent Command Line
parentCommandLine.description: The complete command-line string passed when the parent process was launched.

startAddress.label: Start Address
startAddress.description: The virtual memory address where a new thread begins execution, pointing to the entry point of the thread's code.

startModule.label: Start Module
startModule.description: The module name where the thread begins execution.

targetFilename.label: Target Filename
targetFilename.description: The complete file path involved in system operations or file operations.

dvcAction.label: Device Action
dvcAction.description: Records the automated response actions taken by security devices against detected threats or anomalous behaviors.

durationTime.label: Duration Time
durationTime.description: The complete duration of the recorded event or operation from start to finish, unit: seconds

regValue.label: Registry Value
regValue.description: The actual configuration data stored in Windows registry key values.

imageLoaded.label: Image Loaded Path
imageLoaded.description: The complete file path of dynamically linked libraries or driver modules loaded during process runtime.

destUserName.label: Destination User Name
destUserName.description: Target principal user identity name for network connections, system access, or security events.

initiated.label: Connection Initiation Type
initiated.description: Identifies whether the network connection was actively initiated by the local endpoint or passively accepted.

sha256.label: SHA-256 Hash Value
sha256.description: Cryptographic hash value of the file content calculated using the SHA-256 algorithm.

destImage.label: Destination Process Image Path
destImage.description: The complete executable file path of the target process in cross-process operations.

destHostName.label: Destination Host Name
destHostName.description: The hostname of the target device in network connections or threat attacks. This could be a NetBIOS name, DNS hostname, or locally configured machine name.

destAddress.label: Destination IP Address
destAddress.description: The target IP address for identifying network communication connections.

srcTransAddress.label: Source Translated Address
srcTransAddress.description: Records the mapped source IP address after Network Address Translation (NAT).

cve.label: CVE ID
cve.description: Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) standard vulnerability identifier

cost.label: Execution Time
cost.description: Records the execution time of commands, scripts, or programs, measured in milliseconds.

cmdContent.label: Command Content
cmdContent.description: The specific command content executed in a computer system or terminal.

clientPrg.label: Client Program
clientPrg.description: Identifier for the client application name used to connect to databases or other services.

transProtocol.label: Transport Protocol
transProtocol.description: Protocol types used at the transport layer of the OSI model.

TCP.label: TCP
TCP.description: Connection-oriented reliable transport protocol that provides sequential packet transmission, error detection, and retransmission mechanisms.

UDP.label: UDP
UDP.description: A connectionless, unreliable transport protocol that provides low-latency data transmission, suitable for real-time applications.

tag.label: Tag
tag.description: A set of tags used to identify the characteristics or classification of an alert.

ccUserName.label: CC User Name
ccUserName.description: A collection of email addresses for recipients in the CC (carbon copy) field of the recorded email.

signed.label: Signed Status
signed.description: Identifies whether the target object contains a valid digital signature certificate.

signature.label: Digital Signature
signature.description: Digital signature or certificate information used to verify the integrity of files or data.

bytesOut.label: Response Bytes Out
bytesOut.description: Total byte count of server response messages for statistical purposes

bytesIn.label: Bytes In
bytesIn.description: Total byte count of client request messages

bccUserName.label: BCC User Name
bccUserName.description: A collection of email addresses for BCC (Blind Carbon Copy) recipients recorded in the email.

startFunction.label: Start Function
startFunction.description: Entry point function name where the new thread begins execution.

callTrace.label: Call Trace
callTrace.description: Function call sequence at thread creation time, including module name and memory address offset.

cvssVector.label: CVSS Vector
cvssVector.description: Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) vector string, which describes the values of various metric dimensions of a vulnerability in a standardized format.

cvssVersion.label: CVSS Version
cvssVersion.description: Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) version number, such as CVSSv3.1

cncve.label: CNCVE Vulnerability Identifier
cncve.description: Unique vulnerability identifier issued by the China National Vulnerability Database (CNCVE).

cnvd.label: CNVD Vulnerability Identifier
cnvd.description: Unique vulnerability identification number issued by the China National Vulnerability Database (CNVD)

cnnvd.label: CNNVD Vulnerability Identifier
cnnvd.description: Unique vulnerability identifier issued by the China National Vulnerability Database (CNNVD)

cvssBaseScore.label: CVSS Base Score
cvssBaseScore.description: The score value calculated by the Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) Base Metric Group, ranging from 0.0 to 10.0.

hostName.label: Host Name
hostName.description: The identifier name of computing devices (servers, workstations, network devices, etc.) in the network. Typically refers to their NetBIOS name (within Windows LAN) or DNS hostname (fully qualified or short name).

userAgent.label: User Agent
userAgent.description: Information identifying the client (user agent) making the request. Contains anonymized details including the client's operating system, browser, and device type.

webServerSoftware.label: Web Server Software
webServerSoftware.description: The name of the server software running the website service.

Low.label: Low Complexity
Low.description: Basic password requirements, typically only specifying the minimum length.

Medium.label: Medium Complexity
Medium.description: Requires mixed character types (letters + numbers) with medium length requirements.

High.label: High Complexity
High.description: Combination of uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters required for high-strength security requirements.

passwordExpirationPolicy.label: Password Expiration Policy
passwordExpirationPolicy.description: Password validity period (in days) as required by the password policy.

errorMessage.label: Error Message
errorMessage.description: Detailed error description information returned by the recording system, service, or application.

sql.label: SQL Statement
sql.description: Standardized Query Language (SQL) statement submitted to the database for execution.

requestParameters.label: Request Parameters
requestParameters.description: Parameter content carried in the network request

privilegeList.label: Privilege List
privilegeList.description: The set of permissions owned by the system or file, used to describe access control privileges.

minPasswordAge.label: Minimum Password Age
minPasswordAge.description: Password modification policy requires the minimum number of days a password must be used.

maxPasswordAge.label: Maximum Password Age
maxPasswordAge.description: Maximum password age required by the password policy

forceLogoff.label: Force Logoff
forceLogoff.description: Controls whether to forcibly terminate user sessions upon login time expiration.

lockoutObservationWindow.label: Lockout Observation Window
lockoutObservationWindow.description: The system is used to monitor and record the time range of failed login attempts.

dbVersion.label: Database Version
dbVersion.description: Version number of the Database Management System (DBMS)

confPath.label: Configuration File Path
confPath.description: Configuration file storage path for applications or system services

dataPath.label: Data Path
dataPath.description: Storage path for database or application data files

errPath.label: Error Log Path
errPath.description: Storage path of the application error log file

executablePath.label: Executable Path
executablePath.description: The storage path of the executable file in the file system.

logPath.label: Log Path
logPath.description: Log file storage path for applications or system services.

pluginPath.label: Plugin Path
pluginPath.description: Installation path of the application plugin module

sensitiveFile.label: Sensitive File
sensitiveFile.description: Identifies whether the file contains sensitive data (such as passwords, keys, personal information).

isCrossBorder.label: Is Cross Border
isCrossBorder.description: Identifies whether the file or data involves cross-border transmission.

publicFile.label: Public File
publicFile.description: Indicates whether the file is publicly accessible.

assetPort.label: Asset Port
assetPort.description: The network port number through which the asset provides external services.

icon.label: Icon
icon.description: Graphical representation of an object, using visual symbols to refer to specific entities or functions.

isv.label: Independent Software Vendor
isv.description: Unique identifier for the independent development service provider name of a website, application, or software product.

icp.label: Icp
icp.description: Internet Content Provider (ICP) filing number issued by the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology

pubSecFilingNumber.label: Public Security Filing Number
pubSecFilingNumber.description: Website filing number issued by the public security authority.

url.label: URL
url.description: Record the complete address information of the Uniform Resource Locator (URL).

copyright.label: Copyright
copyright.description: Copyright ownership declaration for digital content

compatibility.label: Compatibility
compatibility.description: Describes the compatibility range of software or hardware with operating system versions.

officialAccountName.label: Official Account Name
officialAccountName.description: Official verified name of the WeChat public account

wechatSubjectName.label: WeChat Subject Name
wechatSubjectName.description: The name of the authenticated entity on the WeChat Official Account Platform.

wechatSubjectType.label: WeChat Subject Type
wechatSubjectType.description: Classification of authentication entity types for WeChat Official Accounts Platform

individual.label: Individual Entity
individual.description: WeChat Official Account entity for personal identity authentication

enterprise.label: Enterprise Entity
enterprise.description: Authenticated WeChat Official Account entity of an enterprise or organization

government.label: Government Entity
government.description: WeChat Official Account entity certified by government agencies

media.label: Media
media.description: WeChat Official Account entity authenticated by media organizations

other.label: Other
other.description: Other types of WeChat Official Account authentication entities

mainboard.label: Mainboard
mainboard.description: Manufacturer and model information of the computer motherboard

memorySize.label: Memory Size
memorySize.description: Total capacity information of the target memory.

diskModel.label: Disk Model
diskModel.description: Hard disk model information of the storage device

managementAddress.label: Management IP Address
managementAddress.description: Network layer address used for out-of-band device management, remote access, and system maintenance.

networkInfo.label: Network Configuration Information
networkInfo.description: Network configuration information of network devices or virtual machines.

env.label: Environment Variable
env.description: Environment variables configured in the operating system or containers

systemRequirement.label: System Requirement
systemRequirement.description: Describes the minimum or recommended system configuration requirements necessary for the normal operation of software or hardware products.

assetAddress.label: Asset IP Address
assetAddress.description: IP address recorded in the asset management system

vlanId.label: VLAN ID
vlanId.description: A unique numeric identifier for IEEE 802.1Q Virtual Local Area Networks (VLANs).

serviceType.label: Service Type
serviceType.description: Used to identify the type of application service exposed via network ports or running within the operating system on the endpoint side.

certType.label: Certificate Type
certType.description: Category of digital certificates used to identify different security purposes.

SSL.label: SSL/TLS Certificate
SSL.description: Encryption for secure communication between websites and servers

CodeSigning.label: Code Signing Certificate
CodeSigning.description: Digital signature verification for software and code.

ClientAuth.label: Client Authentication Certificate
ClientAuth.description: Used for client authentication and mutual SSL authentication

Email.label: Email Certificate
Email.description: Used for email encryption and digital signatures.

EVSSL.label: EV SSL Certificate
EVSSL.description: Extended Validation SSL Certificate, providing the highest level of identity verification.

SelfSigned.label: Self Signed Certificate
SelfSigned.description: Certificate not signed by a third-party certificate authority

validTime.label: Valid Time
validTime.description: The validity period range of the certificate

securityGroupIds.label: Security Group ID List
securityGroupIds.description: List of unique identifiers for network security groups (Security Groups) assigned by the cloud service provider.

accessControlPolicy.label: Access Control Policy
accessControlPolicy.description: Stored access control configuration information, used to define resource access permissions.

scanPortList.label: Scan Port List
scanPortList.description: Record the set of target port numbers detected during network scanning activities.

scanIpList.label: Scan IP List
scanIpList.description: A collection of target IP addresses detected during network scanning activities.

deviceSerialNumber.label: Device Serial Number
deviceSerialNumber.description: Unique serial identifier assigned by the hardware device manufacturer.

isp.label: Internet Service Provider
isp.description: The organization name of the Internet Service Provider (ISP).

length.label: Length
length.description: The length size of the target object, such as the maximum length limit specified in the database column definition.

columnName.label: Column Name
columnName.description: The logical name of a data column in a database table.

columnType.label: Column Type
columnType.description: Classification of data types for database columns

columnCount.label: Column Count
columnCount.description: Total number of columns defined in the database table.

icmpCode.label: ICMP Code
icmpCode.description: Indicates the response code returned in the ICMP protocol.

dataSourceAddress.label: Data Source Address
dataSourceAddress.description: Device address of the data source

pktsInAndOut.label: Total Packet Count
pktsInAndOut.description: The cumulative total count of packets transmitted bidirectionally in a network interface or session.

bytesInAndOut.label: Total Bytes In And Out
bytesInAndOut.description: The cumulative total of bytes transmitted bidirectionally in a network interface or session.

softwareSerialNumber.label: Software Serial Number
softwareSerialNumber.description: Software serial number, used to uniquely identify software licensing.

busSystemName.label: Business System Name
busSystemName.description: Name identifier of the business system

busSystemVersion.label: Business System Version
busSystemVersion.description: The specific version number of the business system

busSystemId.label: Business System ID
busSystemId.description: Unique identifier of the business system

systemIncludeDevList.label: System Include Device List
systemIncludeDevList.description: Device asset inventory, containing unique identification information such as device type, model, and serial number, used for asset tracking, inventory management, and security audits.

softwareList.label: Software List
softwareList.description: List of third-party applications and software components installed on the system or device.

filePath.label: File Path
filePath.description: The storage directory path of the file in the file system.

attackerInfo.label: Attacker Information
attackerInfo.description: Traceability information of the attacker, including anonymized details such as attacker account, name, email, etc.

fileEncrypted.label: File Encrypted
fileEncrypted.description: Indicates whether the file content is protected by encryption algorithms.

isCdn.label: Is CDN
isCdn.description: Identifies whether the target is a Content Delivery Network (CDN) node.

cdnVendor.label: CDN Vendor
cdnVendor.description: Official name of the Content Delivery Network (CDN) service provider

processCount.label: Process Count
processCount.description: Total number of associated processes running on the current system or asset.

ipVersion.label: IP Version
ipVersion.description: Version identifier of the Internet Protocol (IP)

timesPermin.label: Attempts Per Minute
timesPermin.description: Count the number of specific operations or authentication attempts per minute.

sm3.label: SM3 Hash Value
sm3.description: Cryptographic hash value of the file content calculated using the SM3 algorithm.

webTamperType.label: Web Tamper Type
webTamperType.description: Specifies the specific type of malicious modification to webpage content, structure, or functionality.

contentReplacement.label: Content Replacement
contentReplacement.description: The attacker directly replaces the original content of the website, such as replacing the homepage with a defacement page or a show-off page.

hiddenLinkInjection.label: Hidden Link Injection
hiddenLinkInjection.description: Stealthily embedding malicious links in web pages, typically using SEO techniques to boost the search rankings of illicit websites, making them difficult to detect during normal browsing.

visibleLinkInjection.label: Visible Link Injection
visibleLinkInjection.description: Embedding links in the page that are clearly unrelated to the website's main content, including advertisements or links to prohibited content.

jsScriptHijacking.label: JavaScript Script Hijacking
jsScriptHijacking.description: By embedding malicious JS scripts, search engine crawlers are identified and tampered content is returned to perform traffic hijacking or redirection.

metaTampering.label: Metadata Tampering
metaTampering.description: Tampering with the TDK (Title, Description, Keywords) of a webpage, typically used for SEO cheating or redirecting to illegal websites.

islandPageInjection.label: Island Page Injection
